proscene
Class PSInteractiveCameraFrame

java.lang.Object
  proscene.PSFrame
      proscene.PSInteractiveFrame
          proscene.PSInteractiveCameraFrame
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, PSMouseGrabber
public class PSInteractiveCameraFrame
extends PSInteractiveFrame

The PSInteractiveCameraFrame class represents a PSInteractiveFrame with Camera specific mouse bindings.

A PSInteractiveCameraFrame is a specialization of a PSInteractiveFrame, designed to be set as the PSCamera.frame(). Mouse motions are basically interpreted in a negated way: when the mouse goes to the right, the PSInteractiveFrame translation goes to the right, while the PSInteractiveCameraCameraFrame has to go to the left, so that the scene seems to move to the right.

A PSInteractiveCameraFrame rotates around its revolveAroundPoint(), which corresponds to the associated PSCamera.revolveAroundPoint().

A PSInteractiveCameraFrame can also "fly" in the scene. It basically moves forward, and turns according to the mouse motion. See flySpeed(), flyUpVector() and the PScene.MouseAction.MOVE_FORWARD and PScene.MouseAction.MOVE_BACKWARD.

Constructor Detail

PSInteractiveCameraFrame

public PSInteractiveCameraFrame()
Default constructor.

flySpeed() is set to 0.0 and flyUpVector() is (0,1,0). The revolveAroundPoint() is set to (0,0,0).

Attention: Created object is PSInteractiveFrame.removeFromMouseGrabberPool().

spin

public void spin()
Overloading of PSInteractiveFrame.spin().

Rotates the PSInteractiveCameraFrame around its #revolveAroundPoint() instead of its origin.

Overrides:
spin in class PSInteractiveFrame

setFlySpeed

public void setFlySpeed(float speed)
Sets the flySpeed(), defined in processing scene units.

Default value is 0.0, but it is modified according to the PScene.sceneRadius() when the PSInteractiveCameraFrame is set as the PSCamera.frame().

flyUpVector

public processing.core.PVector flyUpVector()
Returns the up vector used in fly mode, expressed in the world coordinate system.

Fly mode corresponds to the PScene.MouseAction.MOVE_FORWARD and PScene.MouseAction.MOVE_BACKWARD proscene.PScene.MouseAction bindings. In these modes, horizontal displacements of the mouse rotate the PSInteractiveCameraFrame around this vector. Vertical displacements rotate always around the PSCamera X axis.

Default value is (0,1,0), but it is updated by the PSCamera when set as its PSCamera.frame(). PSCamera.setOrientation(PSQuaternion) and PSCamera.setUpVector(PVector) modify this value and should be used instead.

setFlyUpVector

public void setFlyUpVector(processing.core.PVector up)
Sets the flyUpVector(), defined in the world coordinate system.

Default value is (0,1,0), but it is updated by the PSCamera when set as its PSCamera.frame(). Use PSCamera.setUpVector(PVector) instead in that case.

revolveAroundPoint

public processing.core.PVector revolveAroundPoint()
Returns the point the PSInteractiveCameraFrame revolves around when rotated.

It is defined in the world coordinate system. Default value is (0,0,0).

When the PSInteractiveCameraFrame is associated to a PSCamera, PSCamera.revolveAroundPoint() also returns this value.

flyUpdate

public void flyUpdate()
Called for continuous frame motion in fly mode (see PSScene.MOVE_FORWARD).

setRevolveAroundPoint

public void setRevolveAroundPoint(processing.core.PVector revolveAroundPoint)
Sets the revolveAroundPoint(), defined in the world coordinate system.

mouseMoveEvent

public void mouseMoveEvent(java.awt.event.MouseEvent event,
                           PSCamera camera)
Overloading of PSInteractiveFrame.mouseMoveEvent(MouseEvent, PSCamera).

Motion depends on mouse binding. The resulting displacements are basically inverted from those of an PSInteractiveFrame.

Specified by:

mouseWheelEvent

public void mouseWheelEvent(java.awt.event.MouseWheelEvent event,
                            PSCamera camera)
Overloading of PSInteractiveFrame.mouseWheelEvent(MouseWheelEvent, PSCamera).

The wheel behavior depends on the wheel binded action. Current possible actions are ZOOM, MOVE_FORWARD, MOVE_BACKWARD. ZOOM speed depends on #wheelSensitivity() MOVE_FORWARD and MOVE_BACKWARD depend on #flySpeed().

Specified by:
mouseWheelEvent in interface PSMouseGrabber
Overrides:
mouseWheelEvent in class PSInteractiveFrame
See Also:
PSInteractiveFrame.setWheelSensitivity(float)
